captions.text: Good morning, Hank, it's Tuesday - it's question Tuesday,
the day that I answer real question from real Nerdfighter.
That's right, no plural today, just the one question.
[Music]
"Hi, I am a fifteen-year-old girl named Katie."
No, you're not. You're John Green, sitting
slightly farther away from the camera.
Right, no, I realize that, but I'm quoting
a fifteen-year-old girl that wrote us an e-mail.
Ohh! Alright.
"I'm not very popular. How do I get boys to like me?"
Thank you for your question, Katie.
Let me begin by acknowledging that I am not an expert
in the field of fifteen-year-old boys.
In fact, Katie, putting aside the question
of how to get boys to like you,
I don't know how to get boys to like me.
Katie, I don't know if you know this, but all of our videos,
except for the ones that feature giraffe sex as the center screenshot,
are watched by nearly three times more women than men.
So, Katie, my first piece of advice to you is that
if you want to get boys to like you,
you should become a giraffe.
(And then, have yourself videotaped getting
your giraffe freak on.)
So, Katie, from what I can tell,
there are about six ways to get fifteen-year-old boys to like you.
The first way is, of course, to become a giraffe.
The second way is to become World of Warcraft.
The third way is to be something called "hot".
Now, Katie, I would argue that there are at
least two distinct definitions of "hot".
There is the, like, normal human definition
which is "that individual seems suitable for mating",
and then there's the weird culturally-constructed
definition of hot, which means
"that individual is malnourished, and has probably
had plastic bags inserted into her breasts".
Now, boys may find that hot now but I don't
think there's anything inherently hot about it;
like I think if you went back to the eighteenth century and you
asked a fifteen-year-old boy, "Would you like to marry a woman who
has plastic bags needlessly inserted into her breasts?",
that 15-year-old boy would probably be like,
"What's plastic?"
The fourth way to get a boy to like you is to be yourself.
Now, I'm contractually obligated as an adult to give that advice,
even though it doesn't work.
But, yeah, "be yourself", even though no one
has any idea what it means to "be yourself".
Like, whose self would I otherwise be being?
The fifth way to get boys to like you is to meet their expectations by acting like you're an idiot.
There's this famous poem by e.e. cummings
that partly goes,
"-the best gesture of my brain is less than
your eyelids' flutter which says
we are for each other",
and, like, nothing against the quality of that lady's eyelid flutter,
but why is it that women's eyelids are always fluttering
while men's brains are always working?
So, yeah, you can buy into the cultural constructions
that young women are supposed to be stupid and awkward and eyelid-fluttery -
which of course, Katie, is totally easy to do because sometimes you feel stupid,

and sometimes you feel awkward,
and sometimes you wanna get all eyelid-fluttery.

But the great secret of boys
which they are right now denying in the comments
of this very Youtube video is that sometimes they feel stupid,

and sometimes they feel awkward,
and sometimes they feel all eyelid-fluttery!

When you realize that all brains gesture,
and all eyelids flutter,

and everybody feels awkward,
boys will like you (because we will be scared
of your knowledge).
The sixth way to get boys to like you: consider
different boys.
Katie, I have two words for you:
nerd boys.
Katie, I know that nerd boys don't sparkle
in the sunshine,
but they're sensitive, they're caring, they're
sweet, they'll do nice stuff for you,
they're a little bit needy - I will grant you that they're a little bit needy.
Oh, and lastly, let me explain  something briefly to boys:
gentlemen, nerd girls are the world's greatest underutilized romantic resource.
And, guys, do not tell me that nerd girls aren't hot,
because that shows a Paris-Hilton-esque failure to understand hotness.
Hank, I'll see you tomorrow!
I'm so excited for song Wednesday, I gotta
do a little dance!
Dance, dance, dance, dance, closing move!

title: How to Make Guys Like You

comments.text:
I'm seriously concerned about the misinterpretations people have been 
having about this video. Regarding "nerd girls are the world's greatest 
underutilized romantic resource", have in mind this is coming from a 
novelist. Female protagonists are rarely depicted as intelligent in 
romantic books. Quirky, cool, troubled and beautiful seem to be the most 
common tributes. 

About, "malnourished [,,,] and plastic bags needlessly inserted into 
breasts"; John is talking about an odd social construct. He is referencing 
the unattainable expectations men have for women's bodies due to the media. 
To put it simply, he's talking about the Barbie body issue. Unrealistic yet 
accepted as a standard for beauty in society. He isn't saying he likes 
Barbie's looks or dislikes them. He's merely recognizing the social 
construct's existence.﻿
comments.author: D “dguana” Guana

comments.text:

comments.author: Rhonda Caswell

comments.text:
Actually, I have to say that (as a married woman who has two sons with my 
significant man dude of matrimony) though my husband sorta kinda hid his 
nerdness from me in the beginning. Which was fairly easy, because he has 
tattoos and is naturally intimidating and broad shouldered. But, when I 
went to his place, and saw his fairly large collection of Star Trek 
pictures, some of them signed, I was like "...This is another side to a 
person that I have never known, and I kind of like it."
As long as you're not afraid to be yourself (which is hard, granted, but 
doable), you will find someone who is fantastically into all that you're 
into. Or at least accepts it. For instance, I'm not a grand fan of 
Highlander, but I did decide to have the first name of our first born son 
Connor as in Connor McLeod from the clan McLeod. And then my husband 
decided to appeal to my punk/superstitious love and his middle name became 
Dice (which is a sticker on my bass, that I'm not sure he knew about or 
not). He also deals with my love of Anime, Invader Zim and Tank Girl. And 
music, so much music. 
MEETING IN THE MIDDLE! It's ... really all that marriage is, in so many 
many many ways. :3 ﻿
comments.author: SansSkeleton

comments.text:
I am a nerdish girl, dating a nerdish guy. I recently met his *nerd* male 
friend. I really really like him, as a person, not as a potential love 
interest. And therefore, I am trying to find ways to make him like me, 
too... He doesn't seem to dislike me. He blushes if we glance each other at 
the same time and talks to me a bit and doesn't move away, if I sit next to 
him. But he doesn't ask me any of my online nicknames so he could friend me 
nor my phone number, nor does he suggest that we'd meet, if there is no 
apparent reason. He did hang out here in me and my bf's apartment a couple 
of times, when my bf's computer was broken and he was fixing it... After 
that it's always been me asking my bf asking him if we can hang out.
I don't know how to approach him.. I often give people the wrong idea about 
my feelings and intentions and then they think I like them as something 
more than friends. I usually start liking a person as a friend quite soon, 
then I tell them they're nice and that I like them as a person/friend, and 
then they usually tell me I'm weird. If they're as weird as me, we usually 
end up being friends. I have made friends the usual way, too. Random 
talking, that slowly grows deeper and so on. But I find my way much 
quicker, if you really like someone. I really don't want him to get the 
wrong idea. He is my bf's friend, therefore I would never hit on him, not 
even if me and my bf broke up.
Anyway. I find him as a true nerd. He likes computers, anime, swords, video 
games and board games, at least. I find him a bit scary, because they're 
known for about 10 years and me and my bf have known for about 3, he is 4 
years older than me, has more common interests with my bf than me and I've 
only known him for about a month. My bf is something a bit alike. He likes 
anime and video games and Lord of the Rings, Star Trek, Star Wars, Harry 
Potter.
I like Harry Potter a lot and I love theater, but I really really love and 
know pretty much everything about rock and metal music. I have seen some 
anime series and movies. I like movies a lot, except for action. Horror, 
thriller, drama, comedy, it all goes. I only play Sims 2 and some 
occasional online mini games, but I know a lot about games and I can follow 
a conversation very well about the subject. I like board games, except 
chess. The Big Bang Theory is my favorite tv show. I'm just getting into 
all of this "nerd stuff", I'm almost 23. My bf and his friend are almost 27.
Sorry this got so long and rambling, but does anyone have any advice for me 
on how to friend this guy?﻿
comments.author: Zinetha

comments.text:
+Alexis Crow I can try. I am shy, so talking to people can be difficult to 
me. Online chatting would not be a problem. We've met a couple of times 
since I wrote this, and after one evening before leaving he said: "This was 
fun and interesting. See you." After that I was, inside my head, like "yes, 
yes, yes! finally!" After that he has been less shy than before, actually 
talking straight to me and smiling and laughing with me. Progress is still 
slow, but I think we'll get there eventually... I'm the kind of person who 
knows right away if I like someone or not and then if I do, I want to be 
friends. I'm too impatient... It's been two months already, I've made 
friends in two hours sometimes...
comments.author: Zinetha

Personality > looks.

Now, good looks are always nice and if you're cute that's what usually 
sparks most guys to talk to you at first but then it just becomes a bonus. 
(Or it should.) Girls without personality or opinions on anything suck. 
Also, it gives you a lot less to learn about each other which is a big 
reason why you're dating in the first place. (Or it should be.)

If a guy doesn't like you because you're not good looking to his standards 
then find a guy that 1. Likes you for who you actually are and 2. Likes 
your face unlike the last guy. 

Looks aren't everything but they are still relevant no matter how much it 
might suck. ﻿

comments.author: carla roberta

comments.text:
+carla roberta I don't think you can classify any piece of fiction as 
'original'. One because every new invention or discovery is usually based 
on someone eles' work and two because The fault in our stars is in the 
romantic genre which is defiantly a genre which has repeatably been used. 
Most could name 20-25 romantic books. Also John Green learnt everything he 
knows from other people, writers, teachers, philosophers. So any thought he 
may come up with, is all based on any knowledge, morals and experiences he 
has had. This really can be said for everyone the difference is John Green 
applied it. I am not stating that The fault in our stars is not a good book 
but I do not think that your last statement was well thought through. If 
you ask any older family members to read The fault in our stars I am sure 
they could come up with a list of references and other which is somehow 
similar from something they read/watched as a child. A good example is The 
perks of being a wallflower which i find to be a rip off of Adrian Mole, 
which i read when I was eight years old. One statement of your comment i 
can agree with though is the quotes. John Green's sentence structure is 
very advanced and fluent, which is a very difficult task. Finding your 
writing style and making sure it flows has taken me about 5 years. I hope 
you found this interesting. Yours, A Secret Fangirl.
comments.author: Secret Fangirl

How to make girls like you. Over the top charm and cliche nonsense. This is 
why girls are attracted to psychopaths. Psychopaths have a supernatural 
ability to turn the charm on and off like a light bulb, but women don't 
find out they're evil until it's too late. Dracula has the same ability and 
he's a monster too.
I guess my point is don't date charming men. The charming ones are up to 
something. Date men who have no social skills instead. At least they're 
nice guys who won't cheat on you. Date the Peter Parker's of the world and 
throw Prince Charming under the bus. He's an asshole.
That's my advice to the ladies.﻿

That is ridiculous! haha.  I heard about Tinder this last year and I was 
like "why not give it a shot?"  almost everyone was shirtless and says they 
like to go out hiking, to the gym, or participate in some sort of sport.  
What I was looking for...?  Someone I could play some freakin games with 
and not feel so self conscious with.

Also, for some reason people do not put up profiles... only them being 
shirtless...?  I was so confused.

I do not like to bring up feminism (males == females)... not to be confused 
with femi-nazi's (females >= males) often because people on both sides get 
defensive.  But I seriously do feel that it would help males feel more 
comfortable breaking their barriers as well.

comments.text:
+Stephanie Nnadi
The Invasive Predator walks up to the Ring Species and says
*"You look tasty... I'm going to eat you little one"*
*"Eat me? Naw you want my cousin, she lives just around the mountain, she's 
really tasty"*
So the predator goes over to eat his cousin
*"I was told you were much more tasty than your cousin behind me, So I will 
eat you"*
"Why eat me? My Uncle is over there, not to far away, he's much tastier"
Begrudgingly the predator walks around the mountain some more, and gets the 
same promise from the next Ring Species he meets.
Finally the Predator has done a full lap around the mountain range, and 
meets the first member of the Ring Species
*"I.... Was..... Told..... (gasp) That YOU... Are the Tastiest... By that 
one behind me... (weeze)"*
The Ring Species says
*"Who? Him? Naw you can't trust him, he ain't no kin of mine"*
The Invasive Predator dies of starvation
*"Hehe, stupid foreigner should'a asked for directions"*
comments.author: BlankPicketSign

comments.text:
I'm a nerd girl and trust me I am dating a nerdy boy and, even though we 
aren't nerdy about the same things about half the time (because we do have 
individual interests as well as shared interests), it's just amazing when 
you are running around and screaming and bouncing up and down in excitement 
and they completely accept you for that. Then it gets better when you see 
them do the same thing and you just sit there in wonder for a moment, 
watching them being completely joyful about the smallest thing and then 
getting up and running around with them and jumping and sharing in there 
excitement because you become excited that they are excited and you share 
in happiness and joy. You may not have this now, but you will find this and 
it is the most blissful thing and it is worth the wait one hundred times 
over.﻿

comments.author: Nicholas Kenney

comments.text:
Hotness is subjective to what society tells you is hot and what you as a 
person finds attractive. "You like what you like", whether that is a needy 
emo vampire or a vapid underwear model you shouldn't be ashamed of what you 
like of who you are. On the other hand being yourself is subjective to, all 
human beings change their behavior and forms of communication to adapt to 
the cultural group they are dealing with. The idea that you have to be a 
non-conformist prig or a conformist drone is naïve. "Be what you need to be 
when you need to be", but remember to feed your dreams, needs and wants 
when it is all said and done. Try not to be a martyr or a whipping post for 
other people and try not to put other people on pedestals. That is not to 
say you should not sacrifice for others or modify your behavior to please 
others, but do it because it pleases you and serves your interests as well. 
You can't really love and nurture others if you are not willing to do the 
same for yourself. Have consideration for others and yourself in equal 
measure. ﻿

comments.text:
I'm a 17-year-old nerd girl, and I find that more people hit on me online 
than in real life (no one has ever hit on me in real life).
The one thing I've noticed is that the people who do hit on me are usually 
older than me, like people who are 18 or in their 20s.
Guys who are still in high school typically aren't as physically mature as 
girls in high school, and those who are usually still aren't mentally 
mature, so they seek out the one type of girl society says you should go 
for: tall, voluptuous, skinny girls with long hair and delicate features.. 
I have nothing against these girls, they're just like every other girl on 
the inside, it just happens to be that these type of girls are the ones who 
society tells us is the ideal female.
Basically any girl who is seeking a (male) romantic or sexual partner while 
they're 15 probably won't get one, or may get someone older than them 
(that's why some girls say they prefer older guys). It's best to just wait 
until college to pursue romance, or better yet, just let things happen 
naturally.﻿

comments.author: Wewin42

comments.text:
+Wewin42 But then make up isn't a waste if time; its worth is subjective. 

As a gay female that wears make up I often hear that I do not look gay 
because I wear make up and that means that I want guys to find me hot, and 
that makes me both giggle and feel annoyed.

What I think people fail to realize, especially men, is that a lot of women 
do not wear make up for you; they wear it for themselves. Now, you can 
think that make up is a waste of time all you want but if your partner 
likes wearing it....it is in no way a waste.

want to talk to me. So instead I built my confidence by talking to complete 
strangers. This allowed me to feel more comfortable with myself. And these 
strangers have a more objective look at me so I called their opinions over 
those who think they knew me. This built my confidence because the 
strangers would compliment me, since unlike school kids they were mature

so scary and they don't mind being talked to so I was no n longer afraid of 
talking to them.

comments.author: Atticus Floyd

comments.text:
+Lord Voldomort Well, faking it, for me, did nothing real or permanent. I'm 
not talking about dwelling, but assessing and building from there. You 
might just have an epiphany that makes you realize other people aren't as 
important as you thought they were. For example, as a kid, I was always 
told I was ugly, even by my family. Ever heard of "Face only a mother could 
love"?... Yeah, I wasn't even that. I just took their word for it, and 
became severely depressed, purposely destroying my body, cause I thought 
"Well, it's not like I could get any worse". I even feared mirrors, because 
I thought if I looked, I'd see something akin to a monster. Then one day I 
thought "Might as well. It's not like I could look any worse than I imagine 
I do", and examined my features. Shocked as I was, I wasn't half bad. 
Actually decided I was cute, aside from the signs that I had given up on 
taking care of myself. Once I realized they were just pathetic idiots, 
whose opinions didn't hold water, I started taking care of myself FOR 
myself, and natural confidence soon followed. I got friends, partners, and 
the people (family) who formerly called me names would compliment me, but 
I'd just look at them like dirt. Anyway, sorry for making the comment so 
long, but actually liking, and doing things for myself was the only way I 
got real confidence
comments.author: maybewise

actually like yourself, you're gonna settle for someone who doesn't deserve 
you, and/or stay with someone who doesn't treat you well, because you don't 
know your worth. Ok if you fake it to get people interested, but don't fake 
it to get a partner. Look inside yourself and assess why your confidence 
isn't genuine, and work on it.
Faking it until it becomes 'real', just makes you a sociopath.

comments.text:
As a 17 year old girl born with a cleft lip and palate, I've been asked a 
few times why don't I look normal, my response "I look pretty dang normal". 
Now when it comes to dudes (the male ones) I've been told a few  times that 
I scare them and that I can be "hot". Now this worries me mainly because 
although I'm scary (or intimidating), I'm still apparently a kinda 'hot' 
nerd who's never been approached by a teenage dude who was just interested. 
Why does this worry me.... because of questions like "what type of girl is 
approachable?"... "do guys just settle?" ... "if a guy approaches me, are 
they just settling?" Honestly I don't want them to settle or tell me I'm 
pretty and I don't want to be apart of the mass of 'approachable' girls. 
What does that even mean?!. I'd rather hear "Do you want to have a pi 
contest where her person who wins, wins a pie?!" or "Do you think if i spit 
off a really tall building it'll cause damage on it decent?". Stuff like 
that!﻿

comments.text:
I'm not unattractive, but I didn't have a boyfriend until I was 18, and 
that didn't last. It wasn't until I was 25 that I finally met the love of 
my life, and we are now planning our wedding. Don't take it to heart that 
you can't get lots of guys to like you just yet, because at the end of the 
day you only need 1 guy to like you: "the one"... and you want to be 
waiting for him when he finally finds you, not wasting your time with 
someone you were only with to "not be alone". But that's just my advice. :)﻿
